text:
S-X2
111. Jameson, Ethel Etta (Mrs. George Brown)
WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN FARMERS EAT?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Ethel Ethel Johnson (Mrs)
Address: Melfort, Sask.
Birthplace: Hamilton County, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1923
Where did you set up housekeeping? On our homestead near Melfort
Where had you been living before that? With my parents on their farm here.
For how many people did you prepare meals? My husband & myself.
How far was it to your nearest store? 15 miles
How often could a visit be made to the store? Frequently
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar, flour.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Royal Household
In what quantities did you buy it? 100 lbs
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? Do not remember
How much did you use graham flour? Not much
Whole wheat flour? None
Was flour milled locally? Yes
No: far away? What year? 1926
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? Do not remember
What other grain products did you use? V
Cornmeal? V Whole wheat? Some Farina? V
Other? V
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Some
How did you grind it? A farmer neighbor had a small grinding machine operated by horse power. Some people used a coffee grinder to make it for porridge.
Jameson, Mrs. Ethel Etta
Melfort, 1923

1. SKILL AND RESEARCH
   How did you start housekeeping? In eastern Canada 1923.

   There had you been living before that? With my husband on their farm here.

   For how many people did you prepare meals? My husband & myself.

   How far was it to your nearest store? Approximately 1/4 mile.

   How often could a visit be made to the store? Frequently.

   What provisions did you usually buy in those earliest years? Tea, sugar.

2. FOOD AND NUTRITION
   In what quantities did you buy flour? 100 lbs.

   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of flour? $1.50.

   How much did you use wheat flour? 100 lbs.

   How much flour milled locally? 100 lbs.

   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? $0.25.

   What other grain products did you use? Cornmeal.

   Other? None.

   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? Yes.

   For what purpose did you grind? To make flour.

   What grinding machine operated by hand powered some people used coffee grinders to make coffee powder.
3. SUGARS AND SYRUPS

In what quantity did you buy white sugar? 100 lbs.

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? $0.50

What brand of golden corn syrup did you use?

What size of tin of syrup did you usually buy?

At what price?

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? From our own cow.

Butter? Amish butter.

Eggs? Our own hens.

That was the price of butter? $1.25 cents.

Did you pack eggs for inter? Yes.

Did you make butter? No.

Did you make cheese? No.

What kind of cheese?

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef, pork, lamb, wild game, prairie chicken, venison, ducks.

How did you get fresh meat? My father knew how to kill and bleed animals properly.

How often did you get fresh meat? Frequently.

How did you preserve meat? Salted, frozen, or sometimes fried the pork, put it in an earthen crock and covered it with its own rendered fat. This way it would keep well without refrigeration.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? Not in early days.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Pronghorns, antelope, ducks.

Occasionally moose but this was not plentiful in this district.

For how long?

What part did fish play in the family diet? Very seldom used fish until it could be bought on the side as fresh frozen.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh frozen.

Kinds? Mostly white + pickerel.
3. **SUGAR AND CREAM**

In what quantity did you buy sugar? (10 lbs.)

What was the price for a ten pound sack of white sugar? (25¢)

Name brand of flour? (All-purpose)

Price of 4 lb. of flour? (25¢)

At what prices?

---

4. **DIARY PRODUCTS**

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days?

That was the price of butter? (25¢)

Did you purchase from: (Yes)

Did you raise butter? (No)

What kind of cheese?

---

5. **MEAT AND FISH**

What was your meat supply in the early days?

How did you get fresh meat? (Purchased)

How often did you eat fresh meat? (Weekly)

Did you use game? (Yes)

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use fish? (Yes)

---

Was there a garden? (Yes)

What kind of vegetables were grown?

---

7. **FRUIT**

Was there a fruit tree? (Yes)

What kind of fruit was grown?

---

8. **FISH**

Was there a fish pond? (Yes)

What kind of fish were raised?

---

9. **CANNING**

Was there a canner? (Yes)

What kind of food was canned?

---

10. **FREEZING**

Was there a freezer? (Yes)

What kind of food was frozen?

---

11. **CONSERVATION**

Was there a conservation club? (Yes)

What kind of conservation was practiced?

---

12. **OTHER**

Was there any other activity? (Yes)

What kind of activity was it?
6. BEVERAGES

Black tea, remember the brand.

What kind of tea did you buy? At what price?

What kind of coffee did you buy? (beans or ground)

Price?

That other beverages were used?

First shell was found July 1st, 1907 in the new town.

7. VEGETABLES AND DRIED FRUITS

What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you set up housekeeping?

Could you get potatoes at the store?

If not, where from?

What year did you first grow your own supply for the winter of:

Potatoes 1903 Cabbage Carrots Onions

Turnips Beets 1903

In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?

How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?

What weight?

How did the grocer handle prunes (by box)?

What was the price of prunes?

What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, loganberries, raisins, currants or others)?

8. PRESERVING

In the early years did you preserve any foods by drying?

Peas? Corn? Beans? Saskatoons?

Other foods?

What year did you first preserve fruit by canning?

What year did you first preserve vegetables by canning?

What year did you first preserve meat by canning?

Do you still preserve foods by canning or drying?

To what extent?

Did you make your own vinegar?

There has always been an abundance of wild fruit in this district, delicious wild strawberries, raspberries, highbush cranberries, black currants, blue berries, &c., &c., &c., until World War I, we could get sugar to preserve all this fruit. I do not mean the present canning method, when we preserved we used enough sugar so the fruit would keep in such as gallon butter crocks.
6. How much of tea did you buy? 

7. What was the price of potatoes per bushel when you got up housekeeping?

8. Could you get potatoes at the store?

9. If not, where from?

10. What year did you first grow your own vegetables for the winter?

11. In what quantities did you buy white navy beans?

12. How did you buy prunes, (in bulk or by the box)?

13. For did the grocer finally prune (by box)?

14. What was the price of prunes?

15. What other dried fruits did you use in the earliest days? (apples, pears, apricots, peaches, limes, bananas, raisins, oranges or others)?

16. Did you ever use canned goods?

17. Did you ever use preserved sugar?

18. Did you make your own vinegar?

19. Did you make your own water for vinegar?

This has always been an abundant source of food for the district, whether it will be during normal times or during World War II. We could get enough to preserve all the fruit. I do not remember the prices of canned anything, when we preserved our own sugar so the fruit would keep such as golden butter apples.

Baking soda? Yes

Cream of tartar? Yes

Did you make your own baking powder? No

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (Well, river, slough, dugout) Stony Butts & an old rail well, some wells were good.

How far was this water from your home? About 1 mile.

How was it brought to the home? (pail, barrel, tank) Barrel.

Regarding water supply, mention any changes which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

When I lived with my parents 1901 to 1913, the water supply was from the creek. In around 1903 my husband was a teamster, he made large galvanized iron tanks, some would hold 50 barrels, there was abundance grain in those early days so many of the new settlers bought the large tanks. This was my share of household water supply until 1912 when the town installed waterworks.

12. WATER SUPPLY

There did you get water for drinking and for cooking? (e.g., river, dugout)

How far was this water from your home?

Was it brought to the house? (pail, barrel, tank)
13. SOAP

Did you buy laundry soap or make your own? Made some soap.

If you made your own, did you use lye? Yes, I used lye.

What kind of laundry soap did the grocer handle? The first soap I used to buy.

14. FUEL

What fuel did you use in the earliest days? Wood.

Where did you get your fuel? The farmer bought us loads of wood.

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible.

As this was a fairly well wooded district we continued to use wood until about 1911, buying it in cordwood lengths, mostly seasoned poplar. We got a sawing machine run by horse power to cut it into stove wood lengths. I remember what a time my young husband had to buck saw enough wood on Saturday to do other Sunday work upstairs over the tin shop, so it had to be carried upstairs as well. No work was done on Sunday in those days. We were both raised in Methodist homes.

15. METHODS OF COOKING AND TYPES OF UTENSILS

For cooking, did you use an indoor fireplace or open hearth in the earliest days? (Give dates) No.

Did you use an outdoor fireplace or bake oven? (Give dates) No.

By whom was your first cook stove made? McElroy's Winnipeg.

That year was it purchased? 1903.

What types of utensils did you use? (Iron, copper, tin, homemade) Iron, potato pot, some tin, very soon enamel.

For preparing food? (china, earthenware, wooden bowls, other) Enamel.

When did you first see enamel ware? Don't remember.

Aluminum? Don't remember.
13. STAYS

Did you keep laundry busy or make your own?

If you made your own, did you use soap? (Give brand)

First Mrs. Jameson did the regular laundry Saturday and Monday.

14. FUEL

That fuel did you use in the winter at home? (Give brand)

There did you get your fuel? (Give source)

What household items did you have? (Give list)

What food did you buy each week? (Give list)

19. OCCUPATION

When did you start working? (Give date)

20. EDUCATION

What schools did you attend? (Give list)

When did you graduate from high school? (Give date)

26. SWAPPING AND CONTAINERS

List any changes which you result in the containers and contents received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the names of the family or number.

18. That year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in January Sunday

19. Have you ever refused to allow starvation laws living on one or two

20. How many times have you been forced to eat bread and butter?

21. How many times have you been forced to eat bread and butter?
What we called "the pasture" in Oct., but "Kiddal" was the new name brought to western Canada by boys returned from the South African War.

A memorable experience of the first winter I spent in the new house, 1913-14, was having all our food frozen to death. My husband had built a two-roomed house, with living quarters upstairs. This building could not be finished that fall. It had a tarpaper roof. Star paper, with one ply boards covered by sheet metal, but the downstairs downstairs were not finished nor the roof. We could look up and see stars through cracks in the roof and look down and see snow through other cracks. While there was plenty of wood most of the time it had to be buckwheated. We had an air tight heater my husband had made in the township, a good clay stove, but even with these it was not possible to keep cooked. But even with these, it was not possible to keep cooked.

I had considerable difficulty trying to make bread under the above conditions, also as I was the fourth daughter of the Eastman family and married at the early age of 18, I did not have much experience in bread making. If there was no bakery near then.

Bruce Albert.

My husband applied for injuries received in a fall in July 1939.

His picture and an early biography is in Volume 2.

Page 778: History of the Province of Saskatchewan.

Only three of our children are mentioned there as William, Edith and Inez. We later had another son George Gordon who is now working for his Masters degree in Education at the University of Saskatchewan.

William is a member of the Associated Commercial Travellers working for a Saskatoon firm while living in Prince Albert. Edith is Mrs. Stewart Cushing, Caribou Lake, Alberta. Inez is Mrs. W.E. Peterson, Melgort. I have continued to make my home in Melgort, with the exception of two years in Moose Jaw, with my son George when he was an instructor in the Dominion Provincial Youth Training School there. He later served in the R.C.A.F. until the finish of World War II.

If Volume 2 History of Sask. should ever be rewritten would like to have George Gordon's name included in the biography on Page 778.

To the Editor, Jameson, Melgort, Sask.

January 1957
What we called "the great hall" was the rear room. It was a large room with a high ceiling and large windows overlooking the town. The walls were painted a light color and there was a fireplace in the center of the room.

The room was used for various purposes throughout the year. In the fall, it was used for classes and meetings. During the winter, it was used for social gatherings and parties. In the spring and summer, it was used for outdoor activities such as picnics and barbecues.

The room was also used for special events such as the annual town fair. The fair was held in the fall and featured games, rides, and food booths.

In conclusion, the great hall was an important part of the town's life and was used for many different purposes throughout the year.
What we called "the pasture" in Ont., but "Kaal" was the new name brought to Western Canada by boys returned from the South African war.

A memorable experience of the first winter spent in the new farm, 1903-04, was having all our food frozen. Each night, my husband had built a truck shop, 20 x 24, with living quarters upstairs. This building could not be finished that fall, so it had a tar paper roof. Star paper, with one ply boards covered by sheet metal, but the windows downstairs were not finished nor the roof. We could look up and see stars through cracks in the roof and look down and see snow through other cracks. While there was plenty of wood most of the time, it had to be buckwheated. We had an air tight heater my husband had made in the truck shop, a good fireplace heater, any husband had made in the truck shop, a good fireplace stove, but even with those, it was not possible to keep bread, milk, &c, cakes from freezing in an unheated house.

I had considerable difficulty trying to make bread under these conditions, & also as I had the fourth daughter of the Canadian family and married at the early age of 18, I did not have much experience in bread making. So there was no baking sooner than Prince Albert.

My husband applied for injuries received in a fall in July 1939.

His picture and an early biography is in Volume 2, Page 778. History of the Province of Saskatchewan.

Only three of our children are mentioned there as William, Edith and Inez. We later had another son George Gordon who is now working for his Master's degree in Education at the University of Saskatchewan.

William is a member of the Federated Commercial Travellers working for a Canadian firm while living in Prince Albert. Edith is Mrs. Stewart Cushing, Caribou Lake, Alberta, & Inez is Mrs. W.D. Peterson, Wilford. I have continued to make my home in Wilford, with the exception of two years in Moose Jaw with my son George when he was an instructor in the Dominion Provincial Youth Training School there. He later served in the R.C.A.F. until the finish of World War II.

If Volume 2 History of Sask. should ever be rewritten, I would like to have George Gordon's name included in the biography on Page 778.

Ethel E. Johnson, Wilford, Sask.

January 1957
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Up to date electrical methods such as electric range, pressure cookers, wood stoves, etc., empty electric tea kettle, pressure cookers.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In 1900 my father made eleven trips to Prince Albert for supplies that was about 90 miles, with horses & wagon. There had been a hailstorm through the district in 1899 which destroyed any small amount of grain the settlers had tried to grow. By 1901 my father had some wheat which he took to the mill in Prince Albert & bought back flour. By 1916 there was a flour mill in operation in the young town of Delport, but by that time we could also get flour shipped in.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home-canned and home-prepared foods? (Give as many details as possible.)

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in your town or nearby places. In Southern Canada, Indians have not had much choice in quality methods of purchasing food.

In 1900 my father made eleven trips to Prince Albert for supplies that was about 90 miles north by horse and wagon. You could have a habitation through the district in 1899 which destroyed any small amount of grain the settlers had back at the time. By 1916 my father had somewhat started to grow his own food in Prince Albert's hayfield. By 1916 there was a flour mill in Prince Albert and the young town began to grow.
